pullRequest.body:
Generalize `MulActionHom` so that it allows two different monoids acting, related by a morphism. This is inspired by the treatment of (semi)linear maps in mathlib, and allows to refactor them.

Let `M`, `N`, `X`, `Y` be types, with `SMul M X` and `SMul N Y`, and let `φ : M → N` be a map. 
* `MulActionHom φ X Y`, the type of equivariant functions from `X` to `Y`, consists of functions `f : X → Y` such that `f (m • x) = (φ m) • (f x)` for all `m : M` and `x : X`.

Assume that we have `Monoid M`, `Monoid N` and that `φ : M →* N`. For `A`, `B` by types with `AddMonoid A` and `AddMonoid B`, endowed with `DistribMulAction M A` and `DistribMulAction M B`:
* `DistribMulActionHom φ A B` is  the type of equivariant additive monoid homomorphisms from `A` to `B`.

Similarly, when `R` and `S` are types with `Semiring R`, `Semiring S`, `MulSemiringAction M R` and `MulSemiringAction N S` 
* `SMulSemiringHom φ R S` is the type of equivariant ring homomorphisms
  from `R` to `S`.

The above types have corresponding classes:
* `MulActionHomClass F φ X Y` states that `F` is a type of bundled `X → Y` homs  which are `φ`-equivariant
* `DistribMulActionHomClass F φ A B` states that `F` is a type of bundled `A → B` homs  preserving the additive monoid structure and `φ`-equivariant
* `SMulSemiringHomClass F φ R S` states that `F` is a type of bundled `R → S` homs  preserving the ring structure and `φ`-equivariant

## Notation

We introduce the following notation to code equivariant maps
(the subscript index `ₑ` is for *equivariant*) :
* `X →ₑ[φ] Y` is `MulActionHom φ X Y`.
* `A →ₑ+[φ] B` is `DistribMulActionHom φ A B`.
* `R →ₑ+*[φ] S` is `MulSemiringActionHom φ R S`.

When `M = N` and `φ = MonoidHom.id M`, we provide the backward compatible notation :
* `X →[M] Y` is `MulActionHom (@id M) X Y`
* `A →+[M] B` is `DistribMulActionHom (MonoidHom.id M) A B`
* `R →+*[M] S` is `MulSemiringActionHom (MonoidHom.id M) R S`

This more general definition is propagated all over mathlib, in particular to `LinearMap`.

The treatment of composition of equivariant maps is inspired by that of semilinear maps. We provide classes `CompTriple` and `MonoidHom.CompTriple` of “composable triples`, and various instances for them. 

---

- There are no semilinear maps of affine spaces.

nodes.body:
I need some advice here : 
- MulActionHom uses `map_smul'`, with `_root_.map_smul`
- LinearMap was using `map_smul_sl` for (truly) semilinear map, and `map_smul` when the morphism is identity. I have defined abbreviations, possibly not in the correct way.
- The outcome is that Lean hesitates between various `map_smul` functions, so that I have to specify `SemilinearMapClass.map_smul`, which is awkward.

> @ADedecker This branch is redefining MulActionHom in the semilinear style. I went up to a file of yours where you used docs#SMulHom.map_smul. I have the choice between changing it to `MulActionHom.map_smul underscore sl`, or `_root_.map_smul` (because `Filter` is opened, and there is a confusion). What do you feel is preferable?

I think the second one is better, because it's the one we would use if there was no conflict.

@Vierkantor what do you think of the bench result? The total compilation time of mathlib seems more or less the same.

> @Vierkantor what do you think of the bench result? The total compilation time of mathlib seems more or less the same.

I would have expected a slowdown as a tradeoff to the extra expressivity. Since the total difference is `837,353 mld.` instructions (i assume that's 8 × 10^11?) that would translate to 1-2 minutes extra build time over the whole of mathlib spread out over N cpu cores. Since that's less than I would have expected, and there are no specific heartbeat bumps according to `git diff $(git merge-base origin/master HEAD) HEAD | rg maxHeartbeat`, I count it as a positive sign.
That's good. BTW there is now a conflict...

The two failing issues are due to the linter. 
One is `iterate_one`, and the other has been added when I restored the `@[simp]` following one of the earlier comments.
I have no idea of how these should be solved adequatly, except by removing the `@[simp]` tag. 
(Lint says one can change priority : then should it be higher than 100 or lower?)

This PR is starting to look good: I went through all the files and tried to figure out which fixes can be reverted, and there's barely any regressions now!

@AntoineChambert-Loir first, let me say a big thank you for taking on this massive project. Aside from / in addition to my comments below, there are several general comments that would make review easier.

1. reverting any style changes will make the diff smaller and therefore easier to review.
2. reverting any changes to proofs which were not really necessary will make the diff smaller and therefore easier to review (especially with a PR like this where it's hard to tell if a change was really necessary or not, and why).
3. Please update the PR description with a much more detailed description of the changes in this PR. That's what will go into the git history, so it should be well documented for such a big change. (also, I think the `id_eq` comment no longer applies)

After you have addressed these issues, please ping me on GitHub or Zulip and I will request a few reviews from people so that we can get this finished up soon!

I went through the files up to PiTensorProduct and I think we're still on the right track. The shortcut `FunLike` instance should help with some of these build issues.
Some initial comments.
This PR is starting to look good: I went through all the files and tried to figure out which fixes can be reverted, and there's barely any regressions now!

@AntoineChambert-Loir first, let me say a big thank you for taking on this massive project. Aside from / in addition to my comments below, there are several general comments that would make review easier.

1. reverting any style changes will make the diff smaller and therefore easier to review.
2. reverting any changes to proofs which were not really necessary will make the diff smaller and therefore easier to review (especially with a PR like this where it's hard to tell if a change was really necessary or not, and why).
3. Please update the PR description with a much more detailed description of the changes in this PR. That's what will go into the git history, so it should be well documented for such a big change. (also, I think the `id_eq` comment no longer applies)

After you have addressed these issues, please ping me on GitHub or Zulip and I will request a few reviews from people so that we can get this finished up soon!

[As discussed on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.236057.20-.20Add.20equivariant.20morphisms.20and.20adjust.20linear.20maps) I'd reserve `map_smul` for the "true" preserving case. So for the class we'd write:
```suggestion
  map_smulₑ : ∀ (f : F) (c : M) (x : X), f (c • x) = (φ c) • (f x)
```
It's `map_smul'` now, because it has to coincide with what's on LinearMap…

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: MulActionHom in the semilinear style

nodes.body:
I need some advice here : 
- MulActionHom uses `map_smul'`, with `_root_.map_smul`
- LinearMap was using `map_smul_sl` for (truly) semilinear map, and `map_smul` when the morphism is identity. I have defined abbreviations, possibly not in the correct way.
- The outcome is that Lean hesitates between various `map_smul` functions, so that I have to specify `SemilinearMapClass.map_smul`, which is awkward.

Remaining comments which cannot be posted as a review comment to avoid GitHub Rate Limit

> @Vierkantor what do you think of the bench result? The total compilation time of mathlib seems more or less the same.

I would have expected a slowdown as a tradeoff to the extra expressivity. Since the total difference is `837,353 mld.` instructions (i assume that's 8 × 10^11?) that would translate to 1-2 minutes extra build time over the whole of mathlib spread out over N cpu cores. Since that's less than I would have expected, and there are no specific heartbeat bumps according to `git diff $(git merge-base origin/master HEAD) HEAD | rg maxHeartbeat`, I count it as a positive sign.
That's good. BTW there is now a conflict...

pullRequest.body:
Generalize `MulActionHom` so that it allows two different monoids acting, related by a morphism. This is inspired by the treatment of (semi)linear maps in mathlib, and allows to refactor them.

Let `M`, `N`, `X`, `Y` be types, with `SMul M X` and `SMul N Y`, and let `φ : M → N` be a map. 
* `MulActionHom φ X Y`, the type of equivariant functions from `X` to `Y`, consists of functions `f : X → Y` such that `f (m • x) = (φ m) • (f x)` for all `m : M` and `x : X`.

Assume that we have `Monoid M`, `Monoid N` and that `φ : M →* N`. For `A`, `B` by types with `AddMonoid A` and `AddMonoid B`, endowed with `DistribMulAction M A` and `DistribMulAction M B`:
* `DistribMulActionHom φ A B` is  the type of equivariant additive monoid homomorphisms from `A` to `B`.

Similarly, when `R` and `S` are types with `Semiring R`, `Semiring S`, `MulSemiringAction M R` and `MulSemiringAction N S` 
* `SMulSemiringHom φ R S` is the type of equivariant ring homomorphisms
  from `R` to `S`.

The above types have corresponding classes:
* `MulActionHomClass F φ X Y` states that `F` is a type of bundled `X → Y` homs  which are `φ`-equivariant
* `DistribMulActionHomClass F φ A B` states that `F` is a type of bundled `A → B` homs  preserving the additive monoid structure and `φ`-equivariant
* `SMulSemiringHomClass F φ R S` states that `F` is a type of bundled `R → S` homs  preserving the ring structure and `φ`-equivariant

## Notation

We introduce the following notation to code equivariant maps
(the subscript index `ₑ` is for *equivariant*) :
* `X →ₑ[φ] Y` is `MulActionHom φ X Y`.
* `A →ₑ+[φ] B` is `DistribMulActionHom φ A B`.
* `R →ₑ+*[φ] S` is `MulSemiringActionHom φ R S`.

When `M = N` and `φ = MonoidHom.id M`, we provide the backward compatible notation :
* `X →[M] Y` is `MulActionHom (@id M) X Y`
* `A →+[M] B` is `DistribMulActionHom (MonoidHom.id M) A B`
* `R →+*[M] S` is `MulSemiringActionHom (MonoidHom.id M) R S`

This more general definition is propagated all over mathlib, in particular to `LinearMap`.

The treatment of composition of equivariant maps is inspired by that of semilinear maps. We provide classes `CompTriple` and `MonoidHom.CompTriple` of “composable triples`, and various instances for them. 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

TODO (?) : 
- The `CompTriple` mechanism may have to be unified
- There are no semilinear maps of affine spaces.

nodes.body:
I need some advice here : 
- MulActionHom uses `map_smul'`, with `_root_.map_smul`
- LinearMap was using `map_smul_sl` for (truly) semilinear map, and `map_smul` when the morphism is identity. I have defined abbreviations, possibly not in the correct way.
- The outcome is that Lean hesitates between various `map_smul` functions, so that I have to specify `SemilinearMapClass.map_smul`, which is awkward.

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - refactor(Algebra/Module): Use coercion from SemilinearMapClass to SemilinearMap

nodes.body: This PR is starting to look good: I went through all the files and tried to figure out which fixes can be reverted, and there's barely any regressions now!

The two failing issues are due to the linter. 
One is `iterate_one`, and the other has been added when I restored the `@[simp]` following one of the earlier comments.
I have no idea of how these should be solved adequatly, except by removing the `@[simp]` tag. 
(Lint says one can change priority : then should it be higher than 100 or lower?)

@AntoineChambert-Loir first, let me say a big thank you for taking on this massive project. Aside from / in addition to my comments below, there are several general comments that would make review easier.

1. reverting any style changes will make the diff smaller and therefore easier to review.
2. reverting any changes to proofs which were not really necessary will make the diff smaller and therefore easier to review (especially with a PR like this where it's hard to tell if a change was really necessary or not, and why).
3. Please update the PR description with a much more detailed description of the changes in this PR. That's what will go into the git history, so it should be well documented for such a big change. (also, I think the `id_eq` comment no longer applies)

After you have addressed these issues, please ping me on GitHub or Zulip and I will request a few reviews from people so that we can get this finished up soon!
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/99f4f4fd-ebf3-48ed-9ae6-4092e550bc0c) for commit e9dee9952addef9df48cdbcc268cf8a11dd24765.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/88adc54e-4e4f-476d-9288-4dade3543cb1/to/99f4f4fd-ebf3-48ed-9ae6-4092e550bc0c) against commit 99969936b9188578c5fc207414e5a24569d80616:
```diff
  Benchmark                               Metric         Change
  =============================================================
+ build                                   linting         -5.6%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Algebra.NonUnitalHom   instructions    75.5%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.Calculus.Implicit     instructions    13.7%
- ~Mathlib.GroupTheory.GroupAction.Hom    instructions    80.2%
```

> The question is whether or not the `@[coe]` attribute is allowed to be applied to bundled morphisms, or whether it is only valid on bare functions. 

This was from the original file, I have no idea of what should be done

OK. It seems I've done everything I was asked to.
The final linter has some complaints, I don't know how to appease them.

@dupuisf can you have a look at the design of this given the analogy with semilinear maps. Note: I'm not asking for a review of the whole thing. If this looks good, then we'll merge it once we deal with the linter issues.
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/139e3a95-4f91-428c-b5e2-16ca29741bb8) for commit 41c8327a1a46db86ff1a531700fd54befbd379b2.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/770dbd5f-54e0-4ec6-9017-7332f22a448a/to/139e3a95-4f91-428c-b5e2-16ca29741bb8) against commit b7ca9253641877128f9c6f4de0e91e74b3b129cd:
```diff
  Benchmark                                            Metric         Change
  ==========================================================================
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Algebra.NonUnitalHom                instructions    60.4%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.NormedSpace.HahnBanach.Extension   instructions    20.6%
- ~Mathlib.GroupTheory.GroupAction.Hom                 instructions    43.8%
```
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/1e96a863-c023-48a9-91f9-f435bcb6222b) for commit 86444104f5102ad24d4143a32ac760b4912c2b3c.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/e7ff74c2-7e51-4968-ae52-2fb6034b26d5/to/1e96a863-c023-48a9-91f9-f435bcb6222b) against commit 6a3812f587f90f24821e5ed6cf155ccc9cc63b62:
```diff
  Benchmark                                                         Metric         Change
  =======================================================================================
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Algebra.NonUnitalHom                             instructions    60.4%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Module.PID                                       instructions     6.3%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.NormedSpace.HahnBanach.Extension                instructions    22.9%
+ ~Mathlib.Analysis.NormedSpace.PiTensorProduct.InjectiveSeminorm   instructions    -6.2%
- ~Mathlib.GroupTheory.GroupAction.Hom                              instructions    43.8%
+ ~Mathlib.RepresentationTheory.GroupCohomology.Resolution          instructions    -3.9%
```

Thanks again for all your work on this @AntoineChambert-Loir !
